content: quote: Originally posted by Ira1945: for the want of a nail a shoe was lost, for the want of a shoe a horse was lost, for the want of a horse a battle was lost. insignificant as you feel it is, it is just another small cog that will prevent and or slow down or limit or make more costly the art of shooting. it is just one more instance where the simple act of being able to purchase used brass will not be viable and this goes to surplus ammo that must now be de milled, you obviously do not participate in the competition side of shooting, but there are thousands that do and none of my rifles are used to rob gas stations, nor to cause pain and agony. right here and now i would like to invite you to attend the national matches at camp perry ohio this august as my guest to see the real sport of high power rifle and service rifle competion I am a shooter and I try to spend at least two days a month at the range during the school year, and 10-15 days a month during the summer months. I primarily shoot .22 cal bench and .45 pistol and purely for my personal enjoyment. Although I consistently shoot 1/2 inch groups with the .22 at 50 yards and 6-8 inch groups at 20 yards with my .45 acp, I do not consider my skills anywhere near competition level. While I do share your concern about the current shortage of ammunition and reloading materials, I fail to see how this relates to your topic heading that this is somehow a politically motivated gun grab. My personal take on this is that it is a market driven result of the past few months rush on firearms and the current hoarding of ammunition. The rush on firearms has abated at the present time and prices are starting to fall, but finding ammunition is becoming an issue now. Even my favorite .22 match ammunition is very difficult to find and the price has increased by at least 10%. And, none of my firearms are used for criminal activities either. In conclusion, neither you nor I have any real knowledge of why the DoD made this decision and can only speculate as to whether or not it was politically motivated. However, in any case it is a very far stretch to equate this decision to a leftist politically motivated effort to take our firearms. That kind of Chicken Little rhetoric only serves to muddy the issue which ultimately hurts our goal of being able to continue to enjoy our hobby. Peace, out

content: quote: Originally posted by Ira1945: for the want of a nail a shoe was lost, for the want of a shoe a horse was lost, for the want of a horse a battle was lost. insignificant as you feel it is, it is just another small cog that will prevent and or slow down or limit or make more costly the art of shooting. it is just one more instance where the simple act of being able to purchase used brass will not be viable and this goes to surplus ammo that must now be de milled, you obviously do not participate in the competition side of shooting, but there are thousands that do and none of my rifles are used to rob gas stations, nor to cause pain and agony. right here and now i would like to invite you to attend the national matches at camp perry ohio this august as my guest to see the real sport of high power rifle and service rifle competion I am a shooter and I try to spend at least two days a month at the range during the school year, and 10-15 days a month during the summer months. I primarily shoot .22 cal bench and .45 pistol and purely for my personal enjoyment. Although I consistently shoot 1/2 inch groups with the .22 at 50 yards and 6-8 inch groups at 20 yards with my .45 acp, I do not consider my skills anywhere near competition level. While I do share your concern about the current shortage of ammunition and reloading materials, I fail to see how this relates to your topic heading that this is somehow a politically motivated gun grab. My personal take on this is that it is a market driven result of the past few months rush on firearms and the current hoarding of ammunition. The rush on firearms has abated at the present time and prices are starting to fall, but finding ammunition is becoming an issue now. Even my favorite .22 match ammunition is very difficult to find and the price has increased by at least 10%. And, none of my firearms are used for criminal activities either. In conclusion, neither you nor I have any real knowledge of why the DoD made this decision and can only speculate as to whether or not it was politically motivated. However, in any case it is a very far stretch to equate this decision to a leftist politically motivated effort to take our firearms. That kind of Chicken Little rhetoric only serves to muddy the issue which ultimately hurts our goal of being able to continue to enjoy our hobby. Peace, out

content: quote: Originally posted by Ira1945: for the want of a nail a shoe was lost, for the want of a shoe a horse was lost, for the want of a horse a battle was lost. insignificant as you feel it is, it is just another small cog that will prevent and or slow down or limit or make more costly the art of shooting. it is just one more instance where the simple act of being able to purchase used brass will not be viable and this goes to surplus ammo that must now be de milled, you obviously do not participate in the competition side of shooting, but there are thousands that do and none of my rifles are used to rob gas stations, nor to cause pain and agony. right here and now i would like to invite you to attend the national matches at camp perry ohio this august as my guest to see the real sport of high power rifle and service rifle competion I am a shooter and I try to spend at least two days a month at the range during the school year, and 10-15 days a month during the summer months. I primarily shoot .22 cal bench and .45 pistol and purely for my personal enjoyment. Although I consistently shoot 1/2 inch groups with the .22 at 50 yards and 6-8 inch groups at 20 yards with my .45 acp, I do not consider my skills anywhere near competition level. While I do share your concern about the current shortage of ammunition and reloading materials, I fail to see how this relates to your topic heading that this is somehow a politically motivated gun grab. My personal take on this is that it is a market driven result of the past few months rush on firearms and the current hoarding of ammunition. The rush on firearms has abated at the present time and prices are starting to fall, but finding ammunition is becoming an issue now. Even my favorite .22 match ammunition is very difficult to find and the price has increased by at least 10%. And, none of my firearms are used for criminal activities either. In conclusion, neither you nor I have any real knowledge of why the DoD made this decision and can only speculate as to whether or not it was politically motivated. However, in any case it is a very far stretch to equate this decision to a leftist politically motivated effort to take our firearms. That kind of Chicken Little rhetoric only serves to muddy the issue which ultimately hurts our goal of being able to continue to enjoy our hobby. Peace, out
